title-group.article-title: Combined Experimental and TDDFT-DFT Computation, Characterization, and Optical Properties for Synthesis of Keto-Bromothymol Blue Dye Thin Film as Optoelectronic Devices

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The present study of permanganate oxidation of bromothymol blue dye comprising secondary alcoholic groups is of course important for obtaining more knowledge on the structure of the compounds as well as the activity of this dye in aqueous alkaline solutions with a particular view on the effect of the existence of the functional groups on the processes and kinetics of this redox method. Furthermore, this work aims to synthesize the keto-derivative as a precursor to dye. Thin-film from the resulting [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] are made by spin coating to use them in the optical device application.

sec.title: Preparation of Ketobromothymol Blue [BTB]Keto
sec.p: The obtained amount of BTB (3.76 g) was dissolved in 250 cm3/H2O at pH ≥ 12. The BTB powder was steadily added to the solution and aggregated formation was prevented by stirring rapidly and vigorously. KMnO4 solution (250 cm3/1.26 g) and NaF (1.5 g) was then added to the BTB solution progressively over 2 h. The obtained solution was stirred for 48 h at 25°C. By using a rotary evaporator, the formed MnF4 was obtained (one fifth of the original solution). The dilute CH3COOH acid used to acidified of concentrated solution part at pH of ca. 5–6. The solution was vacuum-dried and then elementary analysis and IR spectroscopy were performed. 2,4-dinitrophenyl hydrazone and dioxime derivatives were synthesized by reacting with dinitrophenyl hydrazine and hydroxylamine with BTB to obtain the BTB keto-derivative. The resulted of BTB keto-derivative were characterized by FTIR which included the spectral bands at 1720–1600 cm−1 for the carbonyl group of α-ketones.

sec.title: Synthesis of 2,4-Dinitrophenyl Hydrazone Derivative and Dioxime Derivative
sec.p: The BTB keto-derivative was synthesized by the formation of 2,4-dinitrophenyl hydrazone and dioxime derivatives, during reaction with dinitrophenyl hydrazine and hydroxylamine. A BTB ketone solution was heated in a water-bath with a 2,4-dinitrophenyl hydrazine solution and yellow precipitate of the BTB hydrazone derivative was given. The BTB solution ketone gave white precipitate in a water-bath when heated with hydroxylamine. The precipitate was a BTB derivative of the oxime.

sec.title: Fabrication of [BTB]keto Thin Film Using a Spin Coating Method
sec.p: The DMF and methanol solutions were prepared by dissolved different weights of the resulted from [BTB]keto (25 mg, 35 mg, 45 mg, and 55 mg) and filtered off at 25°C. Ultrasonic cleaned optical substrates were fixed deposit [BTB]keto thin film using spin coating/2500 reps. At the optimization condition, the homogenous solution of [BTB]keto was dropped onto the rotating substrate to form films with a thickness ≅ 200 ± 2 nm. The films were dried for 48 h at 25°C in the dark. A digital micrometer with precision detected the thickness of the resulting film (10-3 nm).

sec.title: Computational Details
sec.p: The outcomes of DMol3 computation evaluated molecular structure performance and frequency studies for [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] in the DFT isolated molecule in the gas phase. Estimative proof of functional PBE/GGA association, natural pseudo-positive conservators, and the simple DNP set, programmed for tolerable molecules, were accordingly investigated with DMol3.19 The total value of the plane wave power cut-off utilized in computer calculations was 830 eV. For instance, physical and spectroscopic feats of [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] were determined by the IR features of DMol3, leading to an approximation of GP frequency.

In addition, three factors altering Becke's functional relationship20 with the Lee–Yang–Parr functionals (B3LYP)21 relationship with WBX97XD/6-311G have been established, the form and vibrant regularity (IR), [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] in the gas phase was improved and the nanofluids in the gas-phase have been improved. The program GAUSSIAN 09W System explores symmetrical variables, pictures of enhanced arrangements, energy, and vibration of processed nanocomposite blends. The B3LYP technique based on WBX97XD/6-311 G has provided numerous useful findings for the relationship between the configuration and spectrum of studies reported by our group.22,23 The GAP technique was applied to evaluate the representations of Gaussian and DMOl3 [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] in isolated molecules, deliberate descriptor variations, prototypical data on overall vitality, and the blended use of different modifications with various complications.24

sec.title: Stoichiometry
Combined FTIR Experimental and Simulated DFT
sec.p:
IR spectra of the [BTB]keto dye type and its derivatives have been defined as KBr discs and are summarized with some preliminary assignments of substantial characteristic bands. The keto dye [BTB]keto infrared spectral data and its derivatives are shown in Fig. 1. The [BTB]Keto oxidation product was also characterized by the FTIR detected at frequency 3422 cm−1 characterizing the one –OH group in [BTB]keto, this confirms that oxidation occurs in one –OH within [BTB]. Again, the band at 1598 cm−1 characterizes the C=O of α-ketones; a strong band appears at 2962 cm−1 which characterizes the CH2 in the case of BTB but a weak band appears at 2959 cm−1 in the case of [BTB]keto which indicates a –CH group.26–31 In the FTIR spectra of the component, the enhancement of the OH group absorption band at a wavelength of 1598 cm−1 indicates oxidation of the OH group present in BTB dye to its subsequent keto forms, as seen in Fig. 1a. In the spectra of the keto dye form [BTB]keto, a strong band at 1467 cm–1 is attributable to the C–H bending group.32–36 The three absorption bands which appeared at wavelengths 1341 cm−1, 1165 cm−1, and 1068 cm−1 are attributed to ν(S=O) stretching.37,38 On coordination, the –C=O bond is required to absorb at 1019 cm−1 for C–O stretching due to the potential drift of the lone pair density in the oxygen atom to the carbon atom by a double bond, indicates the coordination of oxygen to the carbon atom.39 The FTIR two bands in keto dye form [BTB]keto at 1281 cm−1 and 858 cm−1 are assigned to the (C=C) bending.40,41 Because 579 cm−1 indicates C-Br stretching, the FTIR spectra of the keto dye type [BTB]keto show many bands and a solid band in 579 cm−1.42Fig. 1
(a–c) FTIR spectra and structure of the [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] and simulation IR.

Tentative assignments for the selected [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] FTIR bands are shown in Fig. 1b and c. The assignments were provided earlier43,44 by comparing the [BTB] spectrum with the [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] spectra by conducting isotopic deuterium substitution experiments in a few cases. The [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] FTIR spectra support the predominance of the presence of hydrazine group (–N=NH–) and imine/oxime group (–CH=N–OH) in the solid phase with all [BTB]keto absorption bands (Scheme 1). This is due to the presence of m(–N=NH–) stretching and ν(–CH=N–OH) at 2866 cm−1 and 1652 cm−1, respectively. The absence of m(–C=O) near 1019 cm−1 and the formation of the characteristic hydrazine bands due to extensive coupling of δ(–NH) at 1551cm−1. The experimental curve is extremely conformed to the simulation curve of Gaussian machines. Fig. 1a, b and c illustrates the comparison between the bands matching to frequency (cm−1) in the experimental FTIR spectra for the [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] for the bands of absorption and the relative shifts with DFT calculations for the [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] gaseous phase.Scheme 1
Speculated reaction of [BTB]keto with 2,4-dinitrophenyl hydrazine and hydroxylamine.

sec.title: Kinetic Measurements
sec.p:
In all kinetic dimensions, pseudo-1st constraints were implemented where the initial BTB concentration transcended that of [MnO4−] with I = 0.2 moldm−3 in NaOH at pH’s ≥ 12 as stated earlier45–47. Kinetic explanations were made either by documenting a decrease in permanganate ion absorption at λ = 525 nm48,49 or an increase in absorption at λ = 610 nm corresponding to the creation of a middle manganate (VI) in a thermostatic cell section at the selected λ = 750 nm with an automated scanning spectrophotometer equipped with a software controller with 1-cm path cells. A typical plot is illustrated in Fig. 2. BTB oxidation by alkaline permanganate was found to occur step by step through the formation of observable intermediate complexes [BTB-MnVIO42−] and/or [BTB-MnVO43−] including transient species of manganate (VI) and/or hypomanganate(V)10,50. As these intermediates build-up, a slow decay takes place to give the product. The naked-eye color detection shifting for the solution mixture from violet-pink (MnVIIO4−), to blue (MnVO43−), green (MnVIO42−), and finally yellow (MnIV) are showed in Fig. 3. The intermediate loss of presence in hypomanganate (V) in Fig. 2 suggests that the production of the reaction did not accumulate such species identified. The unexplained phenomena were somewhat surprising.Fig. 2
The oxidation of BTB by alkaline permanganate. [MnO4−] = 2 × 10−4, [BTB] = 2 × 10−3, [OH−] = 0.15 and I = 0.2 moldm−3 at 30°C.Fig. 3
The color degradation (a) Violet Mn(VII); (b) BTB basic; (c) before Mn(V); (d) Blue Mn(V) ion; (e) Dark green Mn(VI).

title.italic: Computation for Electrostatic Potential [MEP] and Electron Density [ED]

sec.p:
We contrasted the respective MEP maps resulting from initial DMOl3/DFT calculations with the initial molecular orbital calculations/Studio 7.0 materials to explain the [BTB]keto derivatives management structure-activity relationship (SAR)51. The electrostatic potential iso-surfaces (− 15 kcal/mol) for the [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] gas phases are shown in Fig. 4(a, b, c, d, e, and f) to represent the core fragments of 1,2-oxathiolane 2,2-dioxide addition those of the solid and small d-transition analogs and the modestly active 3D derivative. In Figs. 2c, f and 4a, the [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] lone pair area of the MEP iso-surface with a value of − 15 kcal/mol can be seen. Comparable lone pair MEP isosurface can be drawn from the [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] isolated molecules52. The noted 3D of MEPVmin minimum values neighboring the lone pair area of [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] isolated molecule is 0.00, 0.00, and 5.66 × 10−2 kcal/mol accomplished by MEP structure calculation, respectively. The calculated principles of MEPVmax of the dye derivatives as gaseous phase molecule are 6.797 × 10−2, 6.202 × 10−2 and 1.034 kcal/mol done by DMOl3/DFT computations, respectively. The MEPVmin and MEPVmax values are required, as predicted, to have unique magnitudes constructed on the nature of the electronic substituent. For the [KBTB-HA] isolated molecule the most negative quantity of MEPVmax (− 1,034 kcal/mol) is found.53Fig. 4
The DFT computation by using DMOl3 Material studio software programs of (a) MEP of the [BTB]keto; (b) ED of the [BTB]keto; (c) MEP of the [KBTB-DNPH]; (d) ED of the [KBTB-DNPH]; (e) MEP of the [KBTB-HA], and (f) ED of the [KBTB-HA].

The MEPVmin value (0.00 kcal/mol) functions as a lone pair quantitative relevant predictor. Compared to this, in the case of dyes with a substituent with an electron-donating highlight, a more negative MEPVmin is expected to increase the density with electrons around the lone pair region of the nitrogen atoms. Likewise, in order to reduce the negative essence of MEPVmin, an electron withdrawal group is required. The MEPVmin relied on the electronic impact quantities of the coloring methods concentrated on ν(NH) values. MEPVmax is expected to be added to the 1,2-oxathiolane 2,2-dioxide moiety as the σ-donating power of the [BTB-DNPH] isolated molecule matrix. The resulting energy interaction between hydroxylamine and 2,4 dinitrophenyl hydrazine with [BTB]keto isolated molecule moiety will be directly proportionate to the sum of MEPVmax if the 1,2-oxathiolane 2,2-dioxide moiety does not contain significant π-back bonding.54 In most calculations the electron density plots become reasonable with the DNP base sets for the isolated molecule [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] (Fig. 4b, d, and e). The negative electrostatic potential for the macrocyclic plane is visible and distributed symmetrically in all calculations,55 and, dependent on the basis set, the form of both positive and negative lobes varies. As seen in our previous theoretical experiments of the interactions of hydrazine open cyclic keto dyes with hydroxylamine and 2,4 dinitrophenyl hydrazine, the carbon nanocluster-contacting negative lobe contracts while the opposite extends.

Figure 5a shows the dependance on the absorbance (Abs.) of the analyzed wavelength samples (λ) using the UV-3101 SHIMADZU UV–Vis-NIR spectrophotometer. The [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] films show two absorption bands at λ equal (495, 612), (260, 361) and (495,612) nm in most of the visible spectra area, respectively. This shows good miscibility between 2,4-dinitrophenyl hydrazine and hydroxyl amine with [BTB]keto chains. For [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] films (Fig. 5a), the maximum absorption bands at a wavelength (λ) are connected to π → π* electronic transition, respectively. These absorption bands are also connected to the transition of electrons from HOMO to LUMO electronic transition for [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] films.58 Figure 5b shows the absorption (y-axis) and the wavelength (x-axis) for the [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH], and [KBTB-HA] gaseous molecules by employing Gaussian 09w/DFT calculations. From optical properties of [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] gaseous molecules, the characteristic absorption band for the single crystal of dye ketone form and its derivatives that were found at λ = 495 nm for [BTB]keto, λ = 361nm for [KBTB-DNPH] and λ = 495 nm for [KBTB-HA] due to π-π* transition. By contrasting the values of λmax which resulted from the experimental approach and DMOl3 calculations for the area of absorption and curve behavior, it is evident that there is good agreement in most of the wavelengths λmax = 498, 261 and 550 nm considered for [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] gaseous molecule.59,60Fig. 5
(a) Plot wavelength (λ) nm and absorbance for [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] thin films. (b) Plot wavelength (λ) nm and strength for [BTB]keto, [KBTB-DNPH] and [KBTB-HA] gaseous molecule.

sec.title: Comparison of DMOl3/DFT Methods
Conclusion
sec.p: The good according among the experimental data of this work indicates that a computational approach can be used to predict the thin film properties on a wide range of conditions. The optoelectrical parameters have been calculated for the film including refractive index, extinction coefficient, dielectric constant, and optical conductivity. CASTEP simulated values are consistent with the experimental values for optical parameters of the thin films. Based on these results, the fabricated thin films can be used as a candidate material for optoelectronic devices and solar cells.
